ygData.messageBody:
They do not need to be excellent in it, but you can only advance to their
level in the language. If they speak at a skill level of 5, then that's all
you'll get out of it. I believe a lot of mages are now doing a "ladder
technique". Basically one mage blows all his training points in Old Erudin,
then jabbers at the other mage till he reaches the same level, then THAT
mage uses all his training points in Old Erudin to increase it even more
then jabber back so now its like they've both put twice their training
points in. After that you've got a marketable language that you can "sell"
for other languages. Offer to jabber in Old Erudin for that High Elf while
he jabbers back in Elder Elvish while that Dwarf jabbers in Dwarven or
whatever. I used to think it was quite horrid to have to spend points to
train in SO many languages, but now I realize that this is actually pretty
cool because they've made languages hard to learn in a way. You won't have
everyone under the sun knowing 14 languages, only those that dedicate a
large amount of time to it (and considering the real world, rightly so).

Malark on Karana

>
> Just some infobits to clarify some things,
>
> 1. You do not need to train in a language to learn it, you
> can learn it by
> hearing somebody who is excellent in the language speak it.
> If you are ever
> riding the boat start up a language class and get all aboard who will
> cooperate to speak in their native tongues. After getting off
> my first boat
> trip I could, barely, speak some Dwarf, and I am a Gnome and
> had never
> trained in any langauge with my Guildmaster. Where we'll get
> to hear Dragon
> or Elder Dragon is beyond me, but I do know the Gypsies that
> sell Combine
> weapons are related to the historic Combine Empire, perhaps
> hanging out by
> Gypsies and listening to them talk to people will give us
> Combine... just an
> idea for somebody to try out. From what I understand you can
> only learn a
> language from hearing from somebody who is excellent in it,
> but I could be
> wrong about that, however I have not been able to get my two fellow
> Enchanters I travel with(my main character is a Gnome
> Enchanter)to learn any
> Dwarf from speaking in it even though I learned it from
> hearing it spoken,
> albeit from a native speaker who is excellent in Dwarf.
>
> 2. As far as combining things in the books, do not put
> anything into the
> books other than what the recipe called for and do not use summoned
> water/items in creating the spell or it won't work. Quills
> and Scrolls
> apparently have no use that people can figure out, probably confusing
> remnants from the Beta just like the Age of Restoration book
> that was pulled
> after the last patch due to it being useless.
>
> Good Luck,
>
